results.title: The Challenge
results.creator_credit: Jack Rogers, Frank Killian and Ampol Petroleum Ltd
results.brief_description: This is a tribute to the Australians who sailed Gretel” in the America’s Cup…” Traces the construction of the Australian challenger, “Gretel”, its trials in America, and finally its efforts in the America’s Cup yacht races.

results.title: Cave temples of India
results.creator_credit: Jagat Murari, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: A vivid reminder of a great past when people created miracles in stone to express devotion to their gods. Shows some of the famous rock-cut shrines, including the caves at Badami, Elephanta and Ellora, dating from the 17th century. Explains the statues depicting the various incarnations of the Hindu deity. Commentary by Berkeley Hill.

results.title: Special Project no. 14: Marlo-Mallacoota-Cape Conran
results.brief_description: The Country Roads Board’s Project no. 14 involves the building of a road from Orbost to Marlo. Shows the first section to Cape Conran and difficulties encountered in clearing and leveling the sandy loam. The area opened by the road has great development potential in its attractive surf beaches, bushland and off-shore oil drilling. Photography by Jim Stirling.

results.title: The Burnie story
results.creator_credit: Associated Pulp and Paper Manufacturers and Cine Service
results.brief_description: The township of Burnie on the north-west coast of Tasmania with a population of 14,000 is the centre of the thriving pulp and paper manufacturing industry. This industry started in 1936 and produces from the forests in the surrounding country, not only timber for the building industry but from the timber waste all types of cardboard, and wrapping paper and even high-grade printing paper. The film shows the up-to-date and powerful machinery which is used from the time a tree is felled until the final paper product is shipped from the Burnie wharves. Afforestation is maintained to ensure the raw material will not be exhausted. Photography: Geoffrey Thompson. Narrated by Ray Chapman.

results.title: 11 Steps to Survival
results.creator_credit: Pierre L'Amare, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film demonstrating steps to take in the event of a nuclear attack. Animated drawings show the effects of atomic explosions in the air and at ground level. How wide an area is affected by light and heat flash, radiation and radio-active fall-out is clearly illustrated. How to build or improvise a fall-out shelter, what to stock in it, when to take shelter and how long to stay there are similarly explained.

results.title: Sunday in Melbourne
results.creator_credit: Paul Olson, Gil Brealey, State Film Centre of Victoria and Melbourne Repertory Film Unit
results.brief_description: An experiment in the creative use of colour visuals, natural sound and dialogue commentary, this film shows the loneliness of the aimless wanderers in the city streets contrasted with those who have companionship on their Sunday. (Award: Special Award for an Experimental Film in the Australian Film Awards, Melbourne Film Festival, 1958) Rights held by Gil Brealey.

results.title: Professional Icing at Home
results.brief_description: Jean Bowring demonstrates how to decorate a birthday cake using simple equipment and techniques. A fruit cake is first covered with fondant icing and then decorated using an icing bag and assortment of tubes. The film concludes with examples of more elaborate work in which the same simple techniques of decoration have been used.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 15 includes the royal couple’s visit to the Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital, followed by a visit to the Victorian regional town of Benalla.

Detailed Description Reel 15:

Opens with Title “Repatriation General Hospital Heidelberg”, followed by footage of crowd outside including flag-waving children. 00:00:25:00 motorcade arrives through ranks of uniformed nurses at attention, and the Queen and Duke exit car and enter hospital building. 00:00:43:00 interior hospital shots; patient in bed wearing medals, patients and staff being greeted and spoken with. 00:01:13:00 outside the building, patients in dressing gowns - some in wheelchairs - gathered on grass. Queen and Duke mingle and chat. 00:02:26:00 Queen and Duke leave in car. 00:02:23:00 close-up of “Royal Train” with coat of arms on front. 00:02:28:00 close-up of train’s name-plate “Harold W Clapp” (named for Sir Harold Winthrop Clapp, former commissioner of Victorian Railways). 00:02:30:00 close-up of Victorian Railways officials in uniform, and train crew. 00:03:04:00 Title “Visit of Northern Victoria Benalla Friday, 5th. March. 1954.” followed by landscape shot out window of moving train, and exterior shots of train travelling and people gathered along tracks. 00:04:25:00 train arrives at Benalla Railway Station. Crowd and close-up shots of people waiting to greet Queen. 00:04:46:00 banner in crowd visible “Wangaratta Technical School”. 00:05:06:00 Queen and Duke exit station - shots of decorated exterior of Benalla Railway Station.

results.title: We call it paradise
results.creator_credit: Australia. Dept. of Defence and Vincent Donovan
results.brief_description: Niree Creed presents this portrait of Garden Island, 6 km. south of Perth and the effect the construction of HMAS Stirling, a naval base, has had on the island and on the town of Rockingham. The construction of the base caused some controversy as squatters, who had lived there for many years, were removed in the process. This film, produced by Defence Public Relations emphasises the benefits the base has brought to the local community.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australia. Dept. of Defence and Vincent Donovan

This film, produced by Defence Public Relations emphasises the benefits the base has brought to the local community.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 14 contains footage of the royal tour visiting Warragul and the Latrobe Valley, followed by a visit to the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research.

Detailed Description Reel 14:

Opens with Title “Warragul”, followed by footage of Queen and Duke exiting railway station (?) and at 00:00:20:00 entering car. 00:00:30:00 flag-waving crowd of children, Queen and Duke mounting dais and waving to crowd. 00:00:43:00 Queen making speech. 00:00:55:00 child presents flowers. 00:01:09:00 locals presented. 00:01:38:00 footage is of crowd along tracks from moving train. 00:01:45:00 footage is of train itself moving along tracks and a distance shot as train moves through very flat grasslands. 00:02:04:00 Title “Visit of His Royal Highness to the University of Melbourne”, followed by very brief footage of flag flying over (presumably) a Melbourne University building. 00:02:17:00 Title “Visit of His Royal Highness to the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research”, followed by shots of the Institute buildings at Royal Melbourne Hospital. 00:03:12:00 the Duke arrives in open car, and greets waiting crowd and children before entering building, where we see some Institute equipment and staff at work. More footage of crowd outside. 00:03:59:00 the Duke exits, moves to car and is driven away.

Reel 14 contains footage of the royal tour visiting Warragul and the Latrobe Valley, followed by a visit to the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research.

Detailed Description Reel 14:

Opens with Title “Warragul”, followed by footage of Queen and Duke exiting railway station (?) and at 00:00:20:00 entering car. 00:00:30:00 flag-waving crowd of children, Queen and Duke mounting dais and waving to crowd. 00:00:43:00 Queen making speech. 00:00:55:00 child presents flowers. 00:01:09:00 locals presented. 00:01:38:00 footage is of crowd along tracks from moving train. 00:01:45:00 footage is of train itself moving along tracks and a distance shot as train moves through very flat grasslands. 00:02:04:00 Title “Visit of His Royal Highness to the University of Melbourne”, followed by very brief footage of flag flying over (presumably) a Melbourne University building. 00:02:17:00 Title “Visit of His Royal Highness to the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research”, followed by shots of the Institute buildings at Royal Melbourne Hospital. 00:03:12:00 the Duke arrives in open car, and greets waiting crowd and children before entering building, where we see some Institute equipment and staff at work. More footage of crowd outside. 00:03:59:00 the Duke exits, moves to car and is driven away.
